'''David Sidney Riley''' (born 8 December 1960) is an English former [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[midfielder]] and [[Forward (association football)|striker]], making 190 league appearances in a nine-year career in [[the Football League]], scoring 40 goals.

He began his career at [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in 1983, and had loan spells at [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] and [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]], before joining [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] for £20,000 in October 1987. In March 1990 he was sold on to [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] for £40,000, and helped the club to two successive promotions into the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]]. He later played for [[Kettering Town F.C.|Kettering Town]], [[Mount Albert-Ponsonby|Ponsonby]] (in New Zealand), [[Boston United F.C.|Boston United]], and [[King's Lynn F.C.|King's Lynn]].

==Playing career==
Riley played for Keyworth United before turning professional with [[Brian Clough]]'s [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in June 1983. He played 12 [[Football League First Division|First Division]] games for the club between April 1984 and 1987, scoring two goals. He was loaned out to [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] in February 1987, and played six [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] games for [[Cyril Knowles]]' side, scoring two goals. He joined [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]] side [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] on loan in 1987, and played twelve league games under [[Noel Cantwell]], scoring two goals.

He joined Third Division club [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] in October 1987, manager [[John Rudge]] splashing out £20,000.<ref name="kent">{{cite book|last=Kent|first=Jeff|title=Port Vale Personalities|publisher=Witan Books|page=21|year=1996|isbn=0-9529152-0-0|url=http://www.amazon.ca/Port-Vale-Personalities-Jeff-Kent/dp/0952915200}}</ref> Scoring on his debut at [[Vale Park]] in a 2–1 win over [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] on 19 October, he was soon a big hit, becoming the club's joint-[[List of Port Vale F.C. seasons|top scorer]] in the [[1987–88 Port Vale F.C. season|1987–88 season]] with 10 goals (along with [[Darren Beckford]]).<ref name="kent"/> He played 48 league and cup games in [[1988–89 Port Vale F.C. season|1988–89]] but [[Bone fracture|broke his leg]] in a 1–1 draw at [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 25 April 1989, and so missed out on the [[1989 Football League Third Division play-off Final|play-off final]] victory over [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]].<ref name="kent"/> He managed to recover, but did not re-capture his first team position and in March 1990 was loaned back to [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]], who were then under [[Mark Lawrenson]]'s stewardship; Peterborough paid £40,000 for his services on a permanent basis the next month.<ref name="kent"/>

He won promotion with the "Posh" in [[1990–91 Football League|1990–91]], helping [[Chris Turner (footballer born 1951)|Chris Turner]]'s side to the fourth and final promotion place in the Fourth Division. They then won a second successive promotion into the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] after beating [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] 2–1 in the [[1992 Football League Third Division play-off Final|play-off final]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]]. Riley then joined [[Football Conference|Conference National]] club [[Kettering Town F.C.|Kettering Town]], and later played for [[Mount Albert-Ponsonby|F.C. Ponsonby]] in New Zealand, before returning to England with non-league sides [[Boston United F.C.|Boston United]] and [[King's Lynn F.C.|King's Lynn]].

==Coaching career==
By March 2011, he was working as under-15s manager at [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theposh.com/page/CentreofExcellence/0,,10427~1022393,00.html|title=Centre of Excellence Staff|date=15 March 2011|work=theposh.com|accessdate=9 July 2011}}</ref>
